p: During drought, cultivated crops, fish and shellfish consumed for food [ 52] may pose an increased risk of disease, which could have implications for human health [ 46]. If treated municipal sewage is used by the agricultural sector for irrigation or to process products due to water shortages there can be an increase in the risk of food-borne illness (e.g., Salmonella, E. coli) [ 46]. Local food production practices and food imported from some countries may need to be monitored more closely under such conditions [ 46].
